title: How to Buy a Flowering Cherry Tree

parts.name: Choosing a Type of Flowering Cherry Tree

steps.headline: Choose a Yoshino cherry tree if you want something that will grow fast.
steps.description: While they are young, Yoshino cherry trees will grow 3 feet (0.91 m) per year. Buy this type of tree if you do not want to wait several years before seeing its blooming potential. Yoshino cherry trees have wide-spreading branches and they grow light pink and white blooms in the spring. Yoshino trees are perfect size for lawns and make great shade trees. These trees can grow up to 35 feet (11 m) tall. Yoshino trees thrive in moderate climates.

steps.headline: Buy an Okame cherry tree to see vibrant pink blossoms in the spring.
steps.description: Okame cherry trees have deep pink blossoms that differentiate them from  other cherry trees. They are also uniformly shaped, measuring about 20 feet (6.1 m) tall and 20 feet (6.1 m) wide at their biggest. Buy this type of cherry tree if you want a decorative, attention-grabbing tree that can withstand cold and warm temperatures. Okame cherry trees bloom without leaves. These trees are very heat tolerant and do well in warm climates.

steps.headline: Get a Kwanzan cherry tree for fluffy pink blossoms and green leaves.
steps.description: Kwanzan cherry trees have a vibrant, springtime look with large, light pink blooms and glossy green leaves. Choose this type of tree if you want ruffled, fluffy blooms that resemble pink carnations. Kwanzan cherry trees can grow up to 30 feet (9.1 m) tall and provide excellent shade for a garden or courtyard. Kwanzan trees are well-suited for moderate or warm climates.

steps.headline: Choose a Weeping cherry tree if you want a fountain-like look.
steps.description: Weeping cherry trees range in size and the color of their blooms. Pick one of these types if you would like a tree with branches that form a draped, cascading look. Weeping cherry trees can grow anywhere from 12–40 feet (3.7–12.2 m) tall at their largest. Weeping cherry trees grow well in moderate climates.

steps.headline: Opt for a Fuji cherry tree to plant in a container or small garden.
steps.description: Fuji cherry trees are the most compact form of flowering cherry trees. They grow white blossoms with pink centers and have wiry branches. Choose this option if you have limited space but still want a slow growing, flowering cherry tree.

steps.headline: Visit local nurseries to inquire about flowering cherry trees.
steps.description: Discuss your landscape with a professional at a local nursery or garden center to get advice about what flowering cherry tree would be best for you. They can tell you about the different types of trees they have available and the main features of each. Once you decide to buy, ask the salesperson to help you pick a tree with healthy roots, leaves, and bark.

steps.headline: Purchase a tree from the Arbor Day Foundation if you live in the U.S.
steps.description: The Arbor Day Foundation is a nonprofit conservation organization that sells trees to raise money for its efforts. Buying a cherry tree from this organization will benefit a good cause and guarantee good quality and care. Search for flowering cherry trees available for sale in your area by visiting https://www.arborday.org/trees/. The speed of delivery will depend on the season and your location.

steps.headline: Buy a tree from a reputable online vendor.
steps.description: A wide selection of trees can be purchased from online nurseries. Reputable websites should provide descriptions and growing conditions for the plants and trees, as well as prices and detailed shipping information. Read reviews of a particular vendor before making a purchase to see if you can expect quality service and a healthy product. For instance, buy a tree from America's largest online nursery, NatureHills.com.

text: Choosing a Type of Flowering Cherry Tree Choose a Yoshino cherry tree if you want something that will grow fast. While they are young, Yoshino cherry trees will grow 3 feet (0.91 m) per year. Buy this type of tree if you do not want to wait several years before seeing its blooming potential. Buy this type of cherry tree if you want a decorative, attention-grabbing tree that can withstand cold and warm temperatures. Okame cherry trees bloom without leaves. These trees are very heat tolerant and do well in warm climates. Get a Kwanzan cherry tree for fluffy pink blossoms and green leaves. Weeping cherry trees grow well in moderate climates. Opt for a Fuji cherry tree to plant in a container or small garden. Fuji cherry trees are the most compact form of flowering cherry trees. They grow white blossoms with pink centers and have wiry branches. Choose this option if you have limited space but still want a slow growing, flowering cherry tree. Purchasing the Tree Visit local nurseries to inquire about flowering cherry trees. Once you decide to buy, ask the salesperson to help you pick a tree with healthy roots, leaves, and bark. Purchase a tree from the Arbor Day Foundation if you live in the U.S. The Arbor Day Foundation is a nonprofit conservation organization that sells trees to raise money for its efforts. Buying a cherry tree from this organization will benefit a good cause and guarantee good quality and care.
